ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about various lab techniques such as electrolysis and titration. Though I didn't do any of the experiments myself since I took this course remotely, seeing an expert do the experiments and hearing him explain the process was really helpful in my learning.
I learned about various chemistry laboratory techniques.
How to write a lab notebook, how to prepare lab reports, as well as basic information on how to use lab equipment as seen in the virtual demonstrations.
I got better at scientific writing, particularly evaluating discrepancies between theoretical and actual values.

This course taught me how to conduct science experiments. I learned how to thoroughly document the steps of the lab procedure and create detailed tables to accurately record data. I learned how to write lab reports, which involved correctly summarizing collected data and creating graphs to depict trends in the data.
learned about how lab equipment works and how to properly carry out experiments
Equally beneficial pairing to chemistry lecture
Basic lab skills for general chemistry
All necessary general chemistry laboratory skills

I have learned so much about the lab techniques used to find and validate experimental values. From atomic spectra to titrations, I feel a lot more comfortable analyzing what techniques would be best suited for a particular experiment.
Even while taking the course remotely, I learned a lot about lab etiquette and equipment use.
Basics of chemical work in the lab setting.
How to convert files into a pdf format and understand how to make good excel graphs and spreadsheets.
I think I learned how to write a lab report and analyze data.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Dr. Cooper is really knowledgeable and really good at explaining topics. The workload was very manageable and it would have been even better had I known that all the quizzes were open note. It was a really good class and I actually felt like I was learning. I heard lots of horror stories about taking lab on sequence but if you have the opportunity and if Dr. Cooper is teaching the lab, take it with him off sequence. you'll actually learn so much more and not feel miserable doing it. This was one of my favorite classes and I usually don't enjoy STEM. 

Weaknesses: I don't know if Dr. Cooper is going to grade us like lab has been graded in the past with grade deflation, but I know he said at the beginning of the semester that that's what would happen. I see no point in having grade deflation and defaulting the average grade to a B+ -- it just pits students against each other (I personally did not try to compete with my peers because of this, but that's a potential consequence of deflating grades). But hopefully that's not how we'll be graded! The only other weakness I can think of is that it took a long time to get feedback on our lab reports and other assignments, so I would always turn in the next lab report without knowing if I was repeating mistakes from my previous lab report since we didn't have our grades back soon enough.
The class is a large workload for being only 0.5 credits.

A strength was that the lab reports were weekly because these provided plenty of opportunities to practice / improve at scientific writing.

A weakness was that these lab reports were _not_ graded on a weekly - or even a monthly - basis. If the instructor kept up with the grading, students would get more out of these weekly assignments.

I really enjoyed the short but detailed pre-lab videos that we watched beforehand, as I found that they really helped me to understand the concepts in each lab. I also appreciated the pre-lab quizzes to keep us accountable for watching the lab videos and reading the lab manual. In class, Dr. Cooper did an excellent job of showing us exactly how procedures are conducted in lab and answering any questions that we had throughout the process. 
In terms of improvements, I have two suggestions. Firstly, it would be helpful if students could receive more regular feedback on assignments such as lab notebooks, as those were very useful in writing the lab reports, so it would be good to catch errors on the lab notebooks before handing in the lab reports where possible. Additionally, though I understand that post-lab quizzes were useful in checking our knowledge of the lab concepts, I found them a little bit redundant. The lab report already required us to debrief the lab thoroughly, so taking a post-lab quiz seemed a little unnecessary.
would be much better in person to actually do the labs but for a virtual learning version it was great
Interactive and great resolution lab

It is such an intense course with the number of things that must be done in one week. A strength is that some grades on specific assignments are dropped which lets the student focus on the concepts more. One of the apparent weaknesses was that the concepts taught at the beginning like solubility were not really grasped because those taking the gen chem lecture unit had not gotten to that topic yet. Also, the questions at the end of the lab report are kind of overkill after spending a bunch of time on the lab report itself.  Some of the questions were a little difficult to figure out what to do, more clarity in the lab report instructions for when making a graph.
Dr. Cooper is great at providing resources to help his students and made the class workload very manageable

Strengths: The lab format, the interactive discussions, and the pre-lab lectures all allowed me clear understanding of the lab and the concepts necessary. In addition, the lab report outlines were very helpful as they helped me plan out my lab notebooks.  Overall, this course was very well laid out and enjoyable. 

Weaknesses: The one thing I would say could be improved would be the timeline of the pre-lab lectures. I wished that I had access to the lectures earlier than the day before as it would have made the pre-lab quizzes a lot less stressful.

The only weakness is the inability to individually perform each experiment. We had to watch and take notes while the professor conducted the entire experiment. However, a strength was that the lab was recorded and we could easily go back and rewatch if we missed any measurements.

The biggest weakness of the course came from the virtual aspect of it as it was not possible to gain hands-on experience in the lab. Besides this, I believe that the course does a good job of guiding students through lab work as well as the process of writing lab reports.

Again a lot of the issues were technologically based as there was not a lot that could be done with the virtual format. However this course really sought to engage the students taking it and to guarantee that everything was understood properly.
I think it was very hard to do Chem Lab virtually but I appreciated the efforts of Professor Cooper. I thought it was difficult to get feedback for Lab Reports as our grades came back late.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having the quizzes be open note was definitely a really good policy and I wish that I had not waited until the end of the semester to ask if the quizzes were open note because that would have saved my grade. The pre lab lectures were clear, and having Dr. Cooper do the experiments really aided my learning because he was really good at explaining everything. I also don't think the open note policy should stop after COVID!
It was definitely useful to be able to watch recordings of the lab procedure even though I took the lab in person.

I think the class was adapted very well to the virtual format. Dr. Cooper and Dr. Lant provided very clear and concise pre-recorded videos to watch regarding the lab material. The class itself always ran smoothly, as Dr. Cooper had several cameras set up that allowed us all to observe the experiment from multiple angles and record data whenever necessary. As far as virtual labs go, this class was wonderful.
maybe have better camera work (have two people doing the lectures so one can film and one can do the experiment
Very interactive
Super well-detailed rundown of lab procedure which is definitely hard to do over camera, but Dr. Cooper managed to do so brilliantly and everything ran incredibly smooth.

The lab was engaging even while online. Often before (or during) conducting an experiment, we would discuss the probable outcomes and the rationale for the changes observed. This engagement helped me understand the labs a lot more.
I didnt have anything that I would improve it at the moment.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would recommend this course to another student. A painless way of doing lab, and I really wished he was teaching lab next semester.
I wouldn't recommend this course unless it is required as a prerequisite.
Yes, and I would recommend to take it concurrently with the lecture course (CHEM 161) because the courses reinforce each other.
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone looking to gain exposure in a lab and build a fundamental understanding of chemistry.
yes - a good course to take with chem 161
If you are required to take a lab then yes
Only if needed as a prereq for something.
Absolutely! This course was a lot of fun, and it was amazing to see how to apply the concepts learned in Chem 161.
If you need it for a pre-req the course is actually not that bad and I bet the lab is better in person, but the experiments seemed pretty cool even online.
I would recommend this course to students who are looking to gain understanding of how the lab is as well as understanding how to handle lab equipment.
Yes I very much enjoyed the course and it was something, although virtual, that was fun to engage with.

comments: Also about one recorded lecture each week

We also watched recorded lectures prior to our lab each week so that we could properly understand the concepts covered in each lab and the purpose of each one.
recorded and live virtual lectures

I have attended in-person laboratory sessions as well.
Recorded lab
Live virtual and recorded lecture.

Zoom
Microsoft Word and Excel
